title: Improve pre-release reporting dashboard
body:
[relnotes](https://github.com/kubernetes/release/blob/master/relnotes) has a mechanism for generating a release preview that is currently used internally at Google, but it would be great to expose this externally so the whole community can keep a regular eye on a release all along the way until it is cut.  The report provides the following:

- Preview of the release notes that will ship with a release
- Pending PRs on the branch (non-master only)
- State of the branch based on jenkins builders/testing

An example run looks like this:
```
$ relnotes --htmlize-md --branch=release-1.6 --preview --markdown-file=/tmp/k8s-release-1.6.md --html-file=/tmp/k8s-release-1.2.html
```
or
```
$ relnotes --htmlize-md --branch=master --preview --markdown-file=/tmp/k8s-master.md --html-file=/tmp/k8s-master.html
```

This issue will track this current list of wants:
- [ ] Expose this externally so that the community can see it
- [ ] Tailor the layout to make it more readable/parsable
- [ ] Based on testing state and the last good git hash that would be chosen for a release, cross out the release notes that would get missed if we released today(now).

It will mean more processing time and github polling to check labels for both PRs for every merge pull.

title: WIP: Add kubelet RPM package builds.
body:
First attempt at the RPMs requested in issue #37. 

This is intended to be relatively self contained build process that can hopefully be integrated into the larger k8s release process, just drop into the
directory and run the build-docker.sh script to launch a Docker
container with appropriate rpm/yum tooling.

Resulting rpms and yum repository metadata will appear in output/
sub-directory and can then just be rsynced, after which client systems just need a simple yum repository file similar to this one I tested with (don't try to use it it's not publically accessible):

```
[root@centos1 ~]# cat /etc/yum.repos.d/kubernetes.repo 
[kubernetes]
name=K8s Repository
baseurl=http://file.rdu.redhat.com/~dgoodwin/kubernetes-rpms/
enabled=1
gpgcheck=0
```

I took an alternate naming scheme from the Debian equivalent in #35 and packaged this as "kubernetes" rather than "kubelet", the reasoning behind this was that between hyperkube, an possible incoming rename to kube, self-hosting, and discussion around kube-master and kube-node etc, I don't know as the kubelet name will survive as the thing a user should be thinking to install. "kubernetes" however, should remain constant at least as a base package in all of this and wherever we end up. This also more closely matches the Fedora RPM packaging today which is further decomposed into the following packages: 

kubernetes.x86_64 : Container cluster management
kubernetes-client.x86_64 : Kubernetes client tools
kubernetes-node.x86_64 : Kubernetes services for node host
kubernetes-master.x86_64 : Kubernetes services for master host

And I suspect we may want to synchronize approaches in the future depending on how all the binary renames play out. 

cc @mikedanese @kubernetes/sig-cluster-lifecycle @detiber @timstclair

In Debian-based distributions, this means auto-starting daemons when you install them.

CNI cosmetics
body:
# Paths

We've had to put CNI bits in `/opt`, as there was no way to tell kubelet to look in other places. As of kubernetes/kubernetes#32151 (already in 1.4), we can pass `--cni-bin-dir=` as well as `--cni-conf-dir=` to kubelet. I makes sense to put the plugins into `/usr/lib/cni` or `/usr/lib/kubelet/cni/bin` or `/usr/libexec/cni` - anything other then `/opt` is good. The reason for this is that traditionally `/opt` is used for installing ad-hoc pieces, not for things installed by the package manager. We could also move `/etc/cni` to `/etc/kubernets/cni`, so we have everything in one directory.
# Package name

I seems like `kuberentes-cni` would be something user has to lookup, calling it `kubernetes-cni-basic-network-plugins` (or just `kubernetes-basic-network-plugins`) would make it more obvious. Word "basic" (or "vanilla" or "generic" or something similar) is also good, so we don't give user the impression that they'll have all the plugins.

title: Fix check_acls in anago
body:
Previously the `check_acls` was using a `case ... in` to find user in ACL list. That only works if the elements after `in` are a shell array--which they used to be, but the elements were moved into a variable (PR https://github.com/kubernetes/release/pull/131) so they are now evaluated as one big element -- hence the check fails for all users.

The fix replaces the pipe character in the `ACL_LIST` with a new line, and then greps for the specified user. If the value is found the check is passed, if it is not the check fails.

Thanks to @bowei for help debugging and fixing.

Fixes https://github.com/kubernetes/release/issues/142

body:
Ivan Žužak support@github.com said:

> For example, I need to search for PRs between tag v1.0..v2.0 and find
> specific labels in PRs merged within that range.
> 
> Today I'm getting the list of PRs to look up with:
> 
> git log $range --format="%s" --grep="Merge pull"
> 
> And then curl'ing each one to see if it has the label I need.
> 
> Is there a way to do this with some api to github so I don't have to make
> hundreds of curl execs?

No, there's no GitHub API that allows you to do exactly what you want, but there's still a way you can help yourself and both speed things up + reduce the number of API calls. Instead of hitting the API over and over again, add a webhook to the project which notifies you when a label has been added or removed from an issue or pull request: http://developer.github.com/webhooks/. That webhook would be pointed at the same system that's doing the API calls right now and that system would store that information locally so that when it needs to know if a pull request has a label -- it doesn't need to make the API call because it already has all the information it needs. In short, you'd cache the information you need locally instead of hitting the API. That should be both faster and reduce the number of API requests.

An alternative to this would be to do what I suggested before -- I think that suggestion is still valid. If you know which label you're looking for, then you can fetch the list of pull requests with that label via the API (by not fetching them individually, but by fetching 100 at a time, which will be 100 times more efficient than what you're doing now). If you then locally do an intersection of that list with the list of pull requests you compiled with the git log command you shared -- that should give you the list of pull requests you need (pull requests that are between some tags AND have label X). Even if you have multiple labels you need to check for -- this approach should still help you significantly reduce the number of API calls you need to make (you could do additional filtering locally, for example, because the list of pull requests you'd get from the API would include the full list of labels, so no need to hit the API again). Does that make sense for your use-case
 ? If not, can you share more details so that we can understand why it doesn't?

title: jobResultsCache.json only keeps one entry
body:
I was investigating why `find_green_build` keeps failing (which is blocking me from cutting 1.6 alpha), and I found that `jobResultsCache.json` only has one entry for each job.

I think it's because `hack/jenkins/upload-to-gcs.sh` expects the JSON file to come back verbatim [as it's printed](https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/blob/a988f71ef06d5b1c128a6e7f28600f69e3b46c4a/hack/jenkins/upload-to-gcs.sh#L220):

```shell
echo "{\"version\": \"${version}\", \"buildnumber\": \"${BUILD_NUMBER}\"," \
       "\"result\": \"${build_result}\"}" >> ${tmp_results}
```

However, it's actually coming back "helpfully" auto-formatted:

```console
$ gsutil -q cat gs://kubernetes-jenkins/logs/ci-kubernetes-e2e-gce/jobResultsCache.json
[
  {
    "buildnumber": "3173", 
    "job-version": "v1.6.0-alpha.0.3641+54ff40670269fb", 
    "version": "v1.6.0-alpha.0.3641+54ff40670269fb", 
    "result": "SUCCESS", 
    "passed": true
  }
]
```

As a result, the [filter to select previous entries](https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/blob/a988f71ef06d5b1c128a6e7f28600f69e3b46c4a/hack/jenkins/upload-to-gcs.sh#L215) matches nothing and all previous builds are erased:

```shell
sed -n 's/^\({"version".*}\),*/\1,/p'
```

title: support reading binary output from bazel-bin/
body:
Currently we assume that release tars are under `$KUBE_ROOT/_output/release-tars`, binaries are under `$KUBE_ROOT/_output/release-stage`, and that we can locally stage things to `$KUBE_ROOT/_output/gcs-stage`.

With Bazel builds, the release tars are under `$KUBE_ROOT/bazel-bin/build/release-tars`, the binaries are under `$KUBE_ROOT/bazel-bin/...` (not one central location), and it's not clear where `gcs-stage` should go.

I'm not sure whether we should try to emulate the non-bazel directory structure for bazel-build binaries (copy/symlink everything into `_output/bazel` or equivalent), update `lib/releaselib.sh` to support bazel paths, or something else entirely.

It's also not clear how bazel crossbuilds might work, and where their output would end up.

title: Disable publicly available cAdvisor
body:
cc @kubernetes/sig-auth-pr-reviews @kubernetes/sig-node-pr-reviews @piosz @DirectXMan12 @mwielgus @kubernetes/sig-cluster-lifecycle-pr-reviews @mtaufen  

After chatting with @DirectXMan12 about what the cAdvisor port actually is used for, I realized that we might be able to turn it off. I tested it locally and it worked just fine, heapster could fetch metrics normally.

Problem: Many kubeadm users spawn their clusters on public VMs from providers like DigitalOcean, Packet, GCE or their own solution where the master has a public IP to the internet. Currently, the `4194` cAdvisor port, is **exposed publicly to anyone**. If the machine has a public IP address; it is **publicly exposed to the internet**. Most users don't know about this nor that they should block `4194` in their firewalls. However, that's unnecessarily complex when we can disable it on the kubelet side. 

Proposed solution: Disabling the publicly available port. Only running cAdvisor internally in the kubelet. cAdvisor metrics are available anyway from `{node-ip}:10250/stats`, but this time with proper authentication and authorization.

For Debian/APT based repositories, I'd suggest to use  similar naming schema, but without `$arch`:
```
kubernetes-xenial-stable-1
kubernetes-xenial-stable-1.8
kubernetes-xenial-latest-1
kubernetes-xenial-latest-1.8
kubernetes-xenial-latest-1.9
kubernetes-xenial-ci-latest-1
kubernetes-xenial-ci-latest-1.8
kubernetes-xenial-ci-latest-1.9
```

Those repositories would be good if they will be populated in similar time and way when `gs://kubernetes-release/release/*.txt` and `gs://kubernetes-release-dev/ci-cross/*.txt` are populated. 
Examples:
-  once 1.8.2 is published and `gs://kubernetes-release/release/stable-1.8.txt` updated for it, set of packages should be uploaded to repository `kubernetes-el7-x86_64-stable-1.8` and corresponding deb `kubernetes-xenial-stable-1.8`. 
- once CI finishes build for branch, corresponding packages uploaded to `kubernetes-xenial-ci-latest-1.8` or similarly `kubernetes-el7-x86_64-ci-latest-1.8`. 


Related: kubernetes/kubernetes#53163 - this makes packages produced during bazel build usable on x86-64. Not ideal case, as we don't have multi-arch support, but better than nothing for now for testing.

I don't have enough knowledge of k8s CI and release infra to develop that myself, but hope people who knows more about it will be able to comment and maybe guide on how to implement that idea.

title: Workflow state, re-entrancy, GCB support.
body:
Workflow state:
* A predefined workflow based on command-line flags is established and presented to the user upon start
* The state is managed in a simple text file `/tmp/anago-runstate` using the names of the entry points, arguments passed in to those entry points and name=value pairs of globals set in those entry points that are saved along with the rest of the state.

Re-entrancy:
* The flow is a mix of stateful and stateless entry points.  The stateless ones are mostly informational and not enumerated in the workflow
* The program can exit at any time for any reason and is fully re-entrant

GCB Support
* Additional splitting up of the build and artifact bundling steps to support GCB calling directly with the kube-cross image
* Setting of a global TMPDIR to make use of the GCB persistent disk
* `--prebuild` and `--buildonly` are added exclusively for use with `--gcb`

Additional fixes/changes to the staging functionality
* Move the disk_space_check to where accurate values can be calculated based on found (or not found) staging areas
* Simplify the staging further by limiting it to all local or all GCS.  The mix provided minimal benefit for added complexity.  The typical use cases don't support the added complexity.

title: Ubuntu 17.10 (GCE image) broken in-pod DNS due to systemd-resolved
body:
(Aware that 17.10 may not be supported yet, I'm using the xenial packages...)

Installing a cluster with kubeadm on GCE's ubuntu-1710 images, I hit the issue described here:

https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/issues/45828

It seems that the Ubuntu 17.10 images (at least those used on GCE) include the problematic `systemd-resolved` installation.

Kubeadm version
```
$ kubeadm version
kubeadm version: &version.Info{Major:"1", Minor:"8", GitVersion:"v1.8.5", GitCommit:"cce11c6a185279d037023e02ac5249e14daa22bf", GitTreeState:"clean", BuildDate:"2017-12-07T16:05:18Z", GoVersion:"go1.8.3", Compiler:"gc", Platform:"linux/amd64"}
```

```
$ cat /etc/os-release 
NAME="Ubuntu"
VERSION="17.10 (Artful Aardvark)"
ID=ubuntu
ID_LIKE=debian
PRETTY_NAME="Ubuntu 17.10"
VERSION_ID="17.10"
HOME_URL="https://www.ubuntu.com/"
SUPPORT_URL="https://help.ubuntu.com/"
BUG_REPORT_URL="https://bugs.launchpad.net/ubuntu/"
PRIVACY_POLICY_URL="https://www.ubuntu.com/legal/terms-and-policies/privacy-policy"
VERSION_CODENAME=artful
UBUNTU_CODENAME=artful
```

```
$ cat /etc/resolv.conf 
# This file is managed by man:systemd-resolved(8). Do not edit.
#
# 127.0.0.53 is the systemd-resolved stub resolver.
# run "systemd-resolve --status" to see details about the actual nameservers.
nameserver 127.0.0.53

search c.tigera-dev.internal google.internal
```

Running these commands seems to work as a workaround (for newly started pods):
```
sed -i 's/ExecStart=\/usr\/bin\/kubelet.*/& --resolv-conf=\/run\/systemd\/resolve\/resolv.conf/' /etc/systemd/system/kubelet.service.d/10-kubeadm.conf
systemctl daemon-reload
systemctl restart kubelet
```

I was slightly surprised by that since GCE's DNS server is on a link local IP from the host namespace.  Nevertheless, with that patch in place, I can successfully ping internet addresses from inside the dnsmasq container, which was not working without that.

body:
The file /etc/systemd/system/kubelet.service.d/10-kubeadm.conf is not declared as config file. Each update keeps overwriting the customisation one has to do when configuring kubelet.
Kubelet's options should not be put in an override.
One option for packaging is to put all variables in a /etc/sysconfig/<kubelet> and source this file in the kubelet service unit.
Something like this :

[Unit]
Description=kubelet: The Kubernetes Node Agent
Documentation=http://kubernetes.io/docs/

[Service]
EnvironmentFile=-/etc/sysconfig/kubelet
ExecStart=/usr/bin/kubelet $KUBELET_ARGS
Restart=always
StartLimitInterval=0
RestartSec=10

[Install]
WantedBy=multi-user.target

This way, one has to build the option line in the /etc/sysconfig/kubelet.
There is no need to do systemctl daemon-reload when the configuration options of kubelet are modified.
This way kubelet options are kept in a configuration file separated from the service unit file.

title: A tool for fetching, contextualizing, organizing, and rendering release notes
body:
This PR adds a tool called `release-notes` and a set of library utilities at `k8s.io/release/pkg/notes` which aim to provide a simple and extensible set of tools for fetching, contextualizing, and rendering release notes.

## Building

To build the `release-notes` tool, check out this repo to your `$GOPATH`:

```
git clone git@github.com:kubernetes/release.git $GOPATH/src/k8s.io/release
```

Run the following from the root of the repository to install dependencies:

```
go get -u github.com/golang/dep/cmd/dep
dep ensure -vendor-only
```

Run the following from the root of the repository to build the `release-notes` binary:

```
go build ./cmd/release-notes
```

Use the `-h` flag for help:

```
./release-notes -h
```

## Running

To generate release notes for a commit range, run:

```
$ export GITHUB_TOKEN=a_github_api_token
$ ./release-notes \
  -start-sha d0a17cb4bbdf608559f257a76acfaa9acb054903 \
  -end-sha   91e7b4fd31fcd3d5f436da26c980becec37ceefe
level=info msg="fetching all commits. this might take a while..."
level=info msg="got the commits, performing rendering"
level=info msg="release notes markdown written to file" path=/var/folders/wp/6fkmvjf11gv18tdprv4g2mk40000gn/T/release-notes-048706664
```

You can also generate the raw notes data into JSON. You can then use a variety of tools (such as `jq`) to slice and dice the output:

```json
[
  {
    "text": "fixed incorrect OpenAPI schema for CustomResourceDefinition objects",
    "author": "liggitt",
    "author_url": "https://github.com/liggitt",
    "pr_url": "https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/pull/65256",
    "pr_number": 65256,
    "kinds": [
      "bug"
    ],
    "sigs": [
      "api-machinery"
    ]
  }
]
```

## FAQ

### What do generated notes look like?

Check out the rendering of 1.11's release notes [here](https://gist.github.com/marpaia/acfdb889f362195bb683e9e09ce196bc).

### What about the `relnotes` shell script? And the `relnotes` go tool?

I'd like to deprecate both of those tools and make sure that whatever automated needs people have can be satisfied by the `k8s.io/release/pkg/notes` package.

### Why formats are supported?

Right now the tool can output release notes in Markdown and JSON.

### Where are the Bazel configs?

I can for sure add bazel configs if we want, but `go build ./cmd/release-notes` isn't so bad :)

### Why isn't this in `toolbox/`

IMO the pattern for Go tools is minimal main files in `cmd/toolname` and well-structured libraries in `pkg/`. Once this is meeting everyone's needs, I'd love to remove `toolbox/` and use this pattern for this repo.

title: kubelet rpm build incorrect location for systemd unit file
body:
According to systemd(1):
> Packages that want to install unit files shall place them in the directory returned by `pkg-config systemd --variable=systemdsystemunitdir`

On RHEL/CentOS 7 (presumably on most RPM-based systems), this is `/usr/lib/systemd/system`. The kubelet RPM, however, installs its unit file in `/etc/systemd/system`.

Looking at rpm/kubelet.spec there's this:

> `install -p -m 755 -t %{buildroot}%{_sysconfdir}/systemd/system/ kubelet.service`


I suspect that it ought to be changed to this:

> `install -p -m 755 -t %{buildroot}%{_unitdir}/ kubelet.service`

title: RFC: Check in RPM spec file updates for patch versions
body:
Back in December 2017 I was asking how RPMs were built for Kubernetes 1.9.x. The Slack thread is here: 
https://kubernetes.slack.com/conversation/C2C40FMNF/p1513780901000151.

I was specifically curious about the RPM spec file, as it has hard-coded values for the major, minor, and patch versions of Kubernetes, and these were out of date at the time (they were for 1.8.x).

@enisoc wrote there are some Google-internal scripts that modify the spec file to update the versions, but for patch releases, those updates are not checked in. Looking at recent history, the spec file jumped from 1.9.0 to 1.11.0, which highlights a gap.

I would like to see these updates checked in if possible, so the community can see the exact spec files used to create the RPMs.

It would also be nice if we come up with a strategy to make it easy to see spec files for different versions (1.10.x vs 1.11.x ...). This could be done with branches/tags in this repository, or with multiple copies of the spec (1 per minor version). I think branches/tags probably makes more sense, but we should keep all the options on the table and discuss.

title: Improve kubernetes release process
body:
# How Release Works

The master branch of the release repo is used to build and release the expected kubernetes packages. The release project will checkout various versions of kubernetes, build the artifacts and release them. 

## The Problem

kubectl, kubeadm, kubelet, and any other rpm/deb package built by the release process suffers from being coupled with the release process and not the code it is building.

The problem with the build and release process being coupled is that different artifacts are built based on the code version, but the release process that defines part of the build is always the same for all versions being built. This causes errors such as v1.8.15 depending on cri-tools when v1.8.15 does not have any of the code necessary to make this dependency make sense. 

## Moving forward

I would like to start collecting information about the blockers for making bazel build process in kubernetes/kubernetes the canonical source.

<hr />

Improving packaging is out of scope for this ticket. I want to focus this ticket on the release process.

cc @kubernetes/sig-cluster-lifecycle-pr-reviews @tpepper

title: `gcbmgr`'s disk is too small when cutting the first beta of a release
body:
The default disk, as configured in [./gcbmgr][gcbmgr-default] seems to be not enough anymore, when the first beta of a release is to be cut and therefore two releases are to be staged (`v1.$n.0-beta.0` and `v1.$((n+1)).0-alpha.0`).

We ran into this error when staging [`v1.14.0-beta.0`][issue] and ran into [this error](https://console.cloud.google.com/cloud-build/builds/81d35470-8c93-47a1-8d11-5c658e10608f?project=kubernetes-release-test):
```
   [...]
Step #1: ================================================================================
Step #1: DISK SPACE CHECK  (4/6)
Step #1: ================================================================================
Step #1:
Step #1: Checking for at least 150 GB on /workspace: FAILED
Step #1: AVAILABLE SPACE: 149
Step #1: THRESHOLD: 150
Step #1: [2019-Feb-19 13:46:32 UTC] common::disk_space_check in 0s
Step #1: FAILED in common::disk_space_check.
Step #1:
Step #1: RELEASE INCOMPLETE! Exiting...
   [...]
```

[gcbmgr-default]: https://github.com/kubernetes/release/blob/a4cf32fd0b19f24974c9f5a3186ba6a344b159ef/gcbmgr#L393
[issue]: ./506

- We hot-fixed it by changing the [default value in `./gcbmgr`][gcbmgr-default] locally to `300`.
- We did not commit / push that change

We should figure out if we even need that much disk, if we just want to bump that value, if we want to make `gcbmgr` more intelligent regarding the disk size calcluation, ...

title: rpms: separate specs by build target, clean dependencies
body:
The one giant specfile is a mess and makes it unclear what are the
actual package dependencies.  This patch splits them and makes a bunch
of cleanups:

Remove stale conditional logic.

Required dependency pinning with '=' is failing at the package
manager runtime dependency resolver when we've published a newer
version of the dependency in the repo, so don't pin, rather require
'>='.

CNI is required across the board at >= 0.7.5, due to a security
vulnerability in older versions.

Kubeadm requires its control plane to be within at least a version as
per https://kubernetes.io/docs/setup/independent/create-cluster-kubeadm/#version-skew-policy

Signed-off-by: Tim Pepper <tpepper@vmware.com>
